Each line represents one entry in𝝅∗superscript𝝅∗\bm{\pi}^{\ast}bold_italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The bold line and closed circles represent the average value.

Figure 5:Finite-sample performance of𝝅^Rsuperscript^𝝅𝑅\widehat{\bm{\pi}}^{R}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTin the adversarial simulation. The top panel shows the root-mean-squared error (RMSE) of𝝅^Rsuperscript^𝝅𝑅\widehat{\bm{\pi}}^{R}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTfor different sample sizes and proportions of Republican voters,pRsubscript𝑝𝑅p_{R}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The bottom panel illustrates the coverage probability of 95% confidence intervals for components of𝝅^Rsuperscript^𝝅𝑅\widehat{\bm{\pi}}^{R}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Asn𝑛nitalic_nincreases, RMSE decreases and coverage approaches the nominal level, with higher variance typically observed at balanced party compositions.
Figure 6:Optimal strategies in the average case setting. Black, blue, red, and green denote the average case optimal among all, Democrat, Republican, and Independent respondents in the sample.
Figure 7:Optimal strategies in an adversarial setting. Blue and red denote the equilibrium strategy for the agent facing Democratic and Republican voters in the primary stage, respectively.

Figure 8:Comparing optimal strategies in the non-adversarial vs. adversarial setting. Blue and red denote the equilibrium strategy for the agent facing Democratic and Republican voters in the primary stage, respectively.
Figure 9:Optimal strategies in the covariate sensitive case, where a different strategy for allocating candidate features can be used for different types of voters.

Figure 10:Comparing the average case and adversarial case results with real historical data. The adversarial case expected optimal outcomes are well within the range of historical experience; the average case outcomes are not. The experimental data from\citetono2019contt were obtained in March of 2016.

Figure 11:Primary analysis. In all plots, they𝑦yitalic_yaxis displays the evaluated log probability under a given policy. Figure sorted from left to right arranged by how strongly their log probabilities trend across partisan ordering.
